description: From Middle English heft, derived from Middle English heven (“to lift, heave”), equivalent to heave +‎ -t (“-th”). For development, compare English weft from weave, cleft from cleave, theft from thieve, etc.

examples: a man of his age and heft

entries.meaning: Heaviness, the feel of weight; heftiness.
examples: A high quality hammer should have good balance and heft.

entries.meaning: The act or effort of heaving; violent strain or exertion.
(US, dated, colloquial) The greater part or bulk of anything.
examples: The turkey's nest was islanded with a fragrant swath , the “heft” of the crop noted and rejoiced over.

verbs.description: heft (third-person singular simple present hefts, present participle hefting, simple past and past participle hefted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lift up; especially, to lift something heavy.
examples: He hefted the sack of concrete into the truck.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To test the weight of something by lifting it.

description: From English and Scots dialect, ultimately from Old Norse hefð (“possession, statute of limitations, prescriptive right”) (compare Old Norse hefða (“to acquire prescriptive rights”)), from Proto-Germanic *habiþō, equivalent to have +‎ -t (“-th”). Cognate with Scots heft, heff (“an accustomed pasture”).

entries.meaning: (Northern England) A piece of mountain pasture to which a farm animal has become hefted (accustomed).
An animal that has become hefted thus.
(West of Ireland) Poor condition in sheep caused by mineral deficiency.

verbs.description: heft (third-person singular simple present hefts, present participle hefting, simple past and past participle hefted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Northern England and Scotland) To make (a farm animal, especially a flock of sheep) accustomed and attached to an area of mountain pasture.
A number of sheets of paper fastened together, as for a notebook.
A part of a serial publication.
examples: The size of "hefts" will depend on the material requiring attention, and the annual volume is to cost about 15 marks.
